title: RL31919
content: According to the Federal Trade Commission, identity theft is the most common complaint from consumers in all 50 states, accounting for over 35% of the total number of complaints received for calendar years 2004-2006. In 2006, out of 674,354 complaints, 36% were related to identity theft. Victim's information was misused for credit card fraud (25%), phone/utilities fraud (16%), bank fraud (16%), employment-related fraud (14%), and government documents/benefits fraud (5%). Identity theft complaints include fraud for credit cards, phone/utilities, bank, employment, government documents/benefits, loans, and other types. Victims may suffer damaged credit records, unauthorized charges, withdrawals, and may need to change personal information like phone numbers and addresses. Concerns about identity theft are heightened due to media reports on data breaches. The report provides an overview of federal laws assisting victims of identity theft in removing inaccurate information from credit records and unauthorized charges from credit accounts. It also discusses laws imposing criminal penalties on those who assume another person's identity through fraudulent documents. The Identity Theft Assumption Deterrence Act prohibits fraud in connection with identification documents, including offenses related to consumer identity theft. Certain offenses under federal laws relate directly to consumer identity theft, making it a crime to produce or possess stolen identification documents without lawful authority. It is also illegal to transfer or use another person's identification without authorization. The punishment for fraud related to identification documents varies depending on the specific offense and the type of document involved. For example, fines or imprisonment of up to 15 years may be imposed for using another person's identification with the intent to commit unlawful activity, if the value obtained is $1,000 or more in a year. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act, signed on July 15, 2004, amends Title 18 of the United States Code to define and establish penalties for aggravated identity theft. Offenses related to identity theft can result in imprisonment for up to twenty years, especially if committed in connection with drug trafficking, violence, or international terrorism. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2004 defines aggravated identity theft as knowingly using another person's identification during certain felonies, with penalties including additional imprisonment terms. The act also requires the United States Sentencing Commission to review and amend its guidelines accordingly. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2004 mandates the United States Sentencing Commission to adjust guidelines for identity theft offenses involving an abuse of position. It also authorizes funding for the investigation and prosecution of identity theft cases. The Fair Credit Reporting Act may provide assistance to victims of identity theft. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) can assist victims of identity theft by helping them remove negative information from their credit files. It outlines consumer rights regarding credit reports and permissible uses for them. The FCRA imposes duties on consumer reporting agencies to ensure accuracy in reported information and allows consumers to sue for violations, such as inaccurate disclosures by credit reporting agencies. Victims of identity theft can also sue for failure to verify information and disclosure of inaccurate data. The FACT Act, signed in 2003, amended the Fair Credit Reporting Act to address identity theft and fraud. Consumers can file suit within two years of discovering a violation or five years of the violation occurring. This national standard aims to prevent identity theft and assist victims. The FACT Act, signed in 2003, amended the Fair Credit Reporting Act to address identity theft and fraud. Credit card issuers must follow procedures to prevent identity theft, such as truncating account numbers on receipts and social security numbers on credit reports. Victims of identity theft have specific protections under the new provisions. Consumers can request fraud alerts to be placed in their credit files for protection against identity theft. These alerts can be maintained for 90 days or extended up to seven years. The alerts are shared with all users of the credit report and must be included with any credit score generated. Victims of identity theft can have information blocked from their credit reports by providing proof of identity theft, an identity theft report, identifying fraudulent information, and confirming it's not related to their transactions. This blocked information must also be reported to the furnisher of the information. Requests for blocking information related to identity theft must be reported to consumer reporting agencies. Victims can request information about the crime and businesses must provide transaction records upon request and verification of identity. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to dispute unauthorized charges and billing errors in credit transactions. It aims to protect consumers from inaccurate credit billing practices. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to dispute charges for goods or services not accepted or delivered, and request proof of purchase. Consumers can file a claim with the creditor to resolve billing errors without having to pay the disputed amount until it is resolved. The act outlines dispute resolution procedures and requires an investigation into the consumer's claims. If a billing error is confirmed, the creditor must correct it. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) provides consumers with a mechanism to challenge unauthorized transactions and have their accounts recredited in case of errors. It establishes the rights and responsibilities of participants in electronic fund transfer systems, limiting a consumer's liability for unauthorized electronic transactions. The EFTA limits a consumer's liability for unauthorized electronic fund transfers to $50 or the amount of unauthorized transfers before notifying the financial institution. Financial institutions must provide documentation of all electronic fund transfers initiated by the consumer. The EFTA limits a consumer's liability for unauthorized electronic fund transfers to $50 or the amount of unauthorized transfers before notifying the financial institution. If a consumer believes there is an error in the documentation provided by the institution, they must notify the institution within 60 days. The institution must investigate the alleged error, determine if an error occurred, and report the results to the consumer within 10 business days. The financial institution must correct errors within one day of determination, may provisionally recredit the consumer's account, and investigate within 10 business days. President's Identity Theft Task Force made recommendations in April 2007. The President's Identity Theft Task Force made final recommendations in April 2007 to crack down on identity theft by harnessing government resources, protecting personal information, educating consumers and businesses, and increasing data security measures. The President's Identity Theft Task Force made recommendations in April 2007 to combat identity theft by improving prosecution and punishment for thieves who steal consumer data and by assisting victims in recovering from the crime. Some recommendations include amending statutes to prosecute identity thieves who target corporations, adding new crimes to the list of offenses for aggravated identity theft, and enhancing laws against theft. Amend statutes to prosecute identity thieves targeting corporations and add new crimes for aggravated identity theft. Penalize creators of malicious spyware and keyloggers, enhance cyber-extortion laws, and ensure sentences can be enhanced for multiple victims. Department of Homeland Security published final rule for State-issued driver's licenses in accordance with REAL ID Act of 2005. The Real ID Rule sets standards for driver's licenses and identification cards to meet the requirements of the REAL ID Act of 2005, including security features, proof of identity, and verification of documents. States have until December 31, 2009, to comply with the extensions granted. The Real ID Rule extends deadlines for states to comply with the REAL ID Act of 2005. States can receive extensions until December 31, 2009, and those meeting security benchmarks can get a second extension until May 10, 2011. States determined to be in compliance must replace all licenses with REAL ID-compliant cards by specific dates depending on birth year. The rule became effective on March 31, 2008.
